markdownRemark.html:
The year 2018 was one of many achievements and experiences and could not finish better: after a long period of negotiation and transition, we concluded the sale of myingresso.com to the Brazilian group EventMix. And I decided to tell you a little more about those 8 years of history, about this son I saw born and grow, and about the lessons I learned in front of my first startup.

How it all began It was 2011, worked as a software developer and had founded Verticis Web Studio a year ago along with André Brunelli and João Zica. I also met Bruno Eustáquio at that time, aspiring entrepreneur, bubbling with ideas and also the experienced and inspiring Paulo Costa. In one of these conversations about how we would dominate the world, at the height of the fever of collective buying sites in Brazil, we had the idea of ​​creating a platform that could offer online tickets to entertainment events. At that time there was no self-service option that could serve the small and medium producers sector and we saw a great opportunity there and decided to dive headlong into this endeavor.

Even in early 2011, after some brainstorming sessions and some work, we already had our brand and some platform prototypes: RockBee was born!

20190116 rockbee First RockBee logo, created in 2011 The first version of the platform was launched in July 2011, and we quickly gained space in the event market in Brazil.

Pivot, Wayra and myingresso.com Already in the first year of operation, we began to detect a problem in our business model, in addition to perceiving a great need of the market: there was at that time a self-service platform for selling tickets (EventBrite and other players were not yet active in the market local). And, in 2011, we were selected from more than 500 startups in Brazil to be accelerated by Wayra Brasil, accelerator of the Telefónica group.

We received an initial contribution, and developed a new version of the platform, which was launched in 2013, while we were inside the Wayra Academy. After 5 years of operation, we had a stable product and we were still looking for a way to grow even more.

In early 2016 we conducted a survey of our producer base and found that perhaps our brand, an English name that did not directly link the product to our audience, could be a possible point of evolution. We then decided to start an arduous process of brand rebranding and repositioning. We did several market studies, brainstorms and after a few months of work and negotiations, we launched myingresso.com:

20190116 branding Branding of myingresso.com We have had considerable growth, we have operated events for 15,000 people. By 2017 we had already moved R $ 4 million and we already had a base of more than 100,000 users.

Growth, expectations and future Despite presenting a sustainable and healthy growth, some points began to make us consider a possible sale of the platform. Profitability was now directly related to investment in marketing and operation, and problems with logistics grew (outsourcing equipment, hiring support staff). As CEO and chief technical officer, I no longer felt that I would be able to make the necessary effort to grow.

In addition, after 7 years at the helm of the project, there was the feeling of neglecting my career as an engineer and software manager after having spent the past 5 years focusing on bringing the best technical solution. Deep down, there was a big feeling that we were not getting 100% of the project’s potential.

In 2017, I received an invitation to lead a team of Front-End developers in Berlin, where the focus of the major technology companies and startups was headed. I thought this was the right time and opportunity, and I decided to take up the challenge. During this period, myingresso.com kept operating normally and I continued to make technical decisions and support in a reduced amount of time.

As early as 2018, the strength of the my-resales.com brand was growing, and the demand for closer care increased. On the other hand, career opportunities and personal growth in Germany only became more evident. That was when, in November 2018, we received the proposal of acquisition by the EventMix group, responsible for most of the major events in the south of the country, and present in several other regions of Brazil.

After considering several factors we decided that the sale would be the best decision for the project, which was already close to 8 years of age. At the end of October, we began the transition, which was completed in early January 2019. The EventMix group decided to keep the mymresso.com brand, the visual identity and the unaltered operation at first. The group still promises to include several improvements in tools and process in the coming months.

Lessons Learned

  1. Execution and timing are keys. An idea has its value close to zero When we had the idea of ​​launching the self-service tool, Brazil was an unexplored market, and no platform had yet been launched. For some organizational issues at the beginning of our acceleration process and also due to our inexperience, it takes longer than expected to launch our first release. At that time, other platforms appeared on the market, and this had a major impact on our market acquisition strategy.

  2. “Trust will not save you from infidelity” At the beginning of our journey, we actively participated in events and made many contacts and partnerships. This has brought us excellent opportunities but also some problems. We had a mentor at the beginning of the project who helped us a lot, had access to all our planning, business plan, spreadsheets. He later declined our equity offer as an advisor and appeared with the lead investor of a competing startup. Nothing that shook or discouraged us, but it was a great learning.

In another context, we also met a famous Brazilian investor, founder of one of the largest national e-commerces. He became close contact, and always made promises of future investments and partnerships, but nothing concrete. Over time he became a personal friend, even calling on his birthday and on special occasions. At one point, he made me the proposal that every entrepreneur would like to hear: I would act as a CTO for one of his projects, develop his platform, and receive $ 3,000.00 monthly, and could still continue to meet the demands of myingresso.com (in the RockBee era). I accepted the proposal, and we started the project.

It was a difficult time for a double trip. In 9 months, the platform was ready and in production. However, the payments were never made as promised. After the completion of the project, the friendship of the beginning was disappearing, and the excuses for not performing the payment went varying. Until at one point all my contacts were no longer answered, I was blocked in all their social networks and disappeared, leaving a debt of $ 14,000.00.

The lesson here is very clear: asking for help, having mentors, partnering and attending events is very important. But always be suspicious. Always ask for NDA’s signature before sharing any information about your business. Document everything, make small contracts, even informal ones.

  1. Personal life while undertaking The entrepreneurial dream is one of the most fascinating things I’ve ever experienced in my life. That feeling of being very close to something grand, that at any moment an unexpected turn will happen. And it is this feeling that makes us believe that every effort is worth it, including sacrificing some aspects of his personal life, believing it to be a “temporary effort” and highly rewarded. Today I see that even if this time is even short and properly rewarded, this sacrifice is not worth it. Sleeping good nights of sleep, having well-deserved leisure time and being close to family and friends is something that will certainly impact directly on the success of your journey!

Future Today I work as Engineering Lead and CTO in one of Europe’s most prominent software development markets, directly involved in the development of startups and new businesses. And so begins 2019, ending a full cycle of growth and learning. And a story of great gratitude!

Long live the “Rock Bee”!
